title: Solidoodle 2 filament rollers - remix for common bearings

description.text:
I like Eobermeyer's original design, but couldn't find the bearing size it is designed for. This design uses standard 608 bearings because they are cheap and sold everywhere. Notes
Update: After using this for months, I noticed it doesn't work well for thin, tall cardboard filament spools. They don't roll as smoothly as wide or plastic spools and I had one fall off.
  • The original design used a 1/4" steel rod but 608 bearings have an 8mm core. A 5/16" rod will fit these perfectly or use bushings to fit in the gap.
  • You will need to sand the bearing holes to get a good press-fit.
  • I've included the SketchUp model and design for easy customization.

comments.text: It looks cool :) But what does it do?
comments.author: Mysli

comments.text: This design is for 2 filament holder end pieces that fit on a Solidoodle2 printer. 2 rods go into the bearings and allow a filament spool to easily rotate on its side. I added a pic to show it in action.
comments.author: Mysli

comments.text:
Oh Neat ;) I was thinking that you could also add a top lid to the printer, maybe redesign the rollers to allow for an acryllic sheet on top and feeding the filament through the hole in the back :D
May i borrow your idea for this? cause it looks awesome :D That way i could also get some more space on the table for the printer

description.text: This is a housing for the various controls and information I want on my 3D printer. The top display holds the Reprap Discount full graphic display (lcd12864), and the ramps kit should be mounted on the midplate. There is a mount for a Raspberry Pi 3B on the back upper wall, that would be for octoprint. Below is mounting space for an ATX PSU, which should be configured to be turned on and off with a toggle on the front panel. There are 3 holes for volt/amp meter displays, which I will connect to the two 12v rails and the 5v rails. In my case, i will be using the always-on 5v circuit (purple atx wire) to power octopi. Run the negative side of the 12v rails thru a shunt for the amp meter, and the positive side of the 12v rails thru a 20amp fuse each. Then use a terminal block to provide a place to connect your electronics. There is enough space on the midplate for the ramps package, as well as a mosfet for the heatbed. I plan to add a exterior panel on the right side panel with connectors for steppers, thermistors, and heated parts, so i can disconnect it from printer if needed.

author: JPas2001

description.text:
This is a Tool designed for a patient who had partially lost his thumb on his left hand (refer to pictures).
It allows him perfom tip grip and hold a nail or a screw.

The thimble had a PLA framework, a silicone Body, and a magnet. The silicone body is fabricated by pouring silicone inside a mold (refer to pictures)

The framework has circles that allow a better attachment of the silicone and has a prolongation to avoid hiperflexion of the patient thumb. The fluted mold shape is for better suspension over the patient stump (its tip was obtained from a 3D scan of the patient hand.).

This object was made for the "Mutual de Seguridad C.Ch.C" from Chile. In a project of the Direction of innovation and development, and the Neuro rehabilitation institute.

Printer Brand:

Leapfrog

Printer:

Creatr

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

15

The process uses 3-D printed polylactic acid (PLA) molds and inside structure, and
Bath silicone .
First silicone is poured inside the mold that surround the exterior of the socket. Then the inside structure, with a magnet inserted on its tip, is embedded inside the silicone and then the mold is closed with the finger shape mold. The silicone is cured at room temperature for 1 hour. Finally, molds are removed and the socket is finished.

You can use moisturizing cream as mold release agent

title: Lawn Chair With Solid Cylinders
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: I modeled this chair from a collectible piece of dollhouse furniture. The cylinders for the cushions are all the same size. I simply duplicated the cylinder and then overlapped each one, adjusting the angle. To make the curved armrests, I used a cylinder and a half sphere. I then used two box tools to remove almost half from each side of the cylinder/sphere group. I was left with what looked like an upside down "U". So, I duplicated the "U" and decreased the width slightly. Then I turned this smaller "U" into a hole tool and grouped, which left a hollowed out shape. I fine-tuned the armrest, using a box tool to cut the legs to the desired height. I used Tinkercad for modeling and printing.

This is a custom slim wallet I made! One side is decorated with gears, but I am open to suggestions for the design on the front. title: Malyan M150 Bed Level Nut - ZigZag Pattern

description.text:
This is a Malyan M150 Bed Leveling knob (Zigzag Pattern) .

Check the Malyan M150 Bed Leveling knob (Swivel Pattern) here - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2068355

I made these knobs for my Malyan M150 since all the other available knobs I liked were either two big and so it would not be possible to move the bed forward completely or not too comfortable to turn.

This one is as big the knob can get on a Malyan M150 while being able to clear the front/back .

Print at 20% to 40% fill for strength.
Print four thumbwheels.

Additional hardware required:

  • 4 M3 nyloc nuts (normal M3 works but bed levelling may have to be done more frequently)
  • 4 M3 washers (they go between the bed and the knob)

author: discostu

title: Catalyst Machineworks - Super Light 3" Camera Mount

description.text:
(This is Version 1. Check the Version 2 for updates.)

Here are some fixed camera mounts for the Catalyst Machineworks Super Light 3" in 20 deg, 30 deg, and 45 deg variants. The STL and Solidworks SLDPRT files are included with the download. Feel free to modify them as you see fit.

Notes:
1) The camera slot is 11.65mm square. It is a nice fit without squeezing down on the camera too much. For a crash proof setup, take a rubberband, loop it over the camera lens, over the top, back, and bottom of the mount, and loop it back over the lens. It's vibration and crash proof.

You can get a tighter fit with a 11.6mm or 11.55mm slot if you don't like the rubberband.

2) Some props will make contact with the tubes. Slight trimming with a razor will fix that.

author: MayDaySr

description.text: I used the diameter of a 608 skate board bearing to get the dimensions of the inner circle. That way a 608 bearing will slide into the inner circle for the spinner to work. I added three other circles on the outside of the spinner base for you. This way you can add objects that weight the same to keep the spinner rotating for a long tome. When we tested it, it was spinning for a max of 5 minutes and 49 seconds.

description.text: Une belle décoration de maison pour ranger ses petites bricole de tout les jours

This is the first thing I've made on my own, and either version is the same in literally every way except for the legs, whichever you like better. I'm still learning how to use Solidworks, and chose this from Minecraft since they are all so blocky and easy to make. Maybe at some point I can make some more complicated prints, but this is what I've got so far!

By the way, I had to experiment with it a little, but I found the best position to print this is on its back, the face pointing upwards. No matter how you put it the legs will always have support, so to take this off I just used a pair of needle nose pliers and it peeled fairly easily. the only part I had a hard time with was the support on the back, but you can just file that down.
Just an edited version ok SamHendersons Design so it can be printed one peace at a time or side by side.

print_settings.Notes:: Printed with Hatchbox ABS. As mentioned in the Summary, I cleaned up the corner grooves with a file after printing.

title: Mount for Full Graphic LCD Controller

description.text:
January 22

I wanted a simple mount to attach a new RepRap Discount Full Graphic Smart Controller to my FolgerTech printer. This is certainly not a case for the electronics. At some point I'll get around to enclosing the electronics and cleaning up the wiring, but that's a project for another day.

The corners of the controller board are squeezed by the four bosses on the mount. I printed these without support and did a little filing to open up the groove for each corner. This mount is attached to the RAMPS / Arduino mounting panel with two M3 screws.

Here is the design in OnShape.

This is for Pittsburgh's Fun a Day, 2017.

description.text: A replacement part for the factory supplied attachment holder that was not satisfactory to me. It was designed for a Shark Lift-Away Deluxe vacuum and am not sure if this would fit any other Shark vacuums.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.4 mm nozzle

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used a a brim instead of rafting, other printers or users who are far more proficient at printing may find you don't need this. My print time was approx 8 hours, but I am new to the 3D printer arena and am learning how to tweak my printer for best performance. Perhaps others can reduce the print time needed.

** Version 2 of this I used a skirt to prime the heads before printing. I used PLA filament from ORB POLYMER and I have since moved over to ideamaker for my slicer and used the following settings. Print time was about 6.5 hours:

fill density: 20%
shells: 2
layer height: .2 mm
extrusion width: .42
default print speed: 40 mm/s
first layer height: .3 mm
first layer speed: 15 mm/s (ensures better bed adhesion for me)
top & bottom fill layers: 5
support speed: 40 mm/s
vertical top & down layers: 1
bed temp: 50 C
extruder temp: 200 C
retraction enabled (some printers may work well without this)
Z hop enabled: .2 mm

Any settings not mentioned here are mostly default settings

Solid Works

I used Solid works to design the piece. I modeled this after the original factory attachment that would only hold 2 of the 4 attachment pieces. There was an issue with the protrusion on the main piece (purple area) as I made the walls too thin. I have since modified this to try and fix this problem. Regardless, even if it doesn't print perfectly it is more for looks. It will not render the piece worthless. It does seem to be a snug fit but it will fit as the can be seen in the pictures.

Version 2 does away with the second post system and instead uses a hole to hold the long extension tube allowing for another attachment to be inserted into the tube. This results in a MUCH better hold for the extension tube which, under version 1, was prone to falling off due to the weight of the tube and constant movement of the vacuum. This should no longer be a problem.

I also moved the post holders higher on the vacuum ring so that more of the part touches the build plate and should require less supports. The middle post is a solid piece. I was trying to eliminate the use of posts running in the center to support the top layer of the post. While it does speed up the printing a small bit, I think it may use too much filament and am considering making it hollow like in version 1. Also added the engraved words "Shark" onto the top middle post.

Version 1 Version 2

Version 1 Version 1 This is version 2 and is a better fit for the attachments Vacuum cleaner attachment holder

This is designed for my Shark Lift-Away Deluxe vacuum. I don't know if this will fit other brands of Shark vacuums. The original holder that it came with only held 2 of the 4 attachments so I designed this to hold all 4 at once. Version 2 is a better fit in my opinion and definitely holds the longer extension tube much better

// Jan 26 2017 corrected the size of the ballbeering hole in the 53mm holder, it was 9mm instead of 7mm
Made some other kind of spool holder. Faster to print than the good orignal, Not so complicate. Save each side with a double nut ...

You can also use ballbeering 608Z if you want.

Internal diameter for the spools: 51mm, 53mm, 57mm

title: Modular Popsicle Stick Picavet Mount Concept

description.text:
The goal is to create a lightweight, modular picavet mount for aerial kite photography.

In my case, I have a Foxeer Legend 1 action camera, but the actual camera mount is a separate print and can be changed for a mount that works for other cameras.

Goal is simplicity and weight minimization. Most connections use zip ties, but there is a 1/4" bolt connecting the camera plate and the picavet mount.

Three pieces:

  • picavet mount plate - connects to the camera mount plate and has notches to guide the zip ties
  • picavet plate - sandwiches the popsicle/craft sticks to the picavet mount plate and has holes to guide the zip ties
  • foxeer mount - the camera mount plate, including zip tie holes

Strengthen bolt hole area

Because of delamination, the bolt hole area is liable to breakage, so post-processing ABS with acetone is probably a good idea. I haven't done it yet.

Popsicle stick configuration

I used wood glue to glue the popsicle sticks.

Assemble

Maybe glue some micro-cell-foam or tub tread to the camera plate to keep the camera from sliding out.

TBD

title: Lulzbot Mini v1.04 camera mount for time lapse recording

description.text:
Mounting bracket for GoPro and similar small cameras with wide angle / fish-eye lens and 1/4" fixing.
Since the camera follows the bed movement, recordings will keep the printed item still and make time lapse movies look "right".

Bracket fits snugly over the Lulzbot Minis front right bed corner. Make sure to install it firmly so that the beds edge corner inserts into the backets seating.

Two versions are available, a high and a low version.
The high version gives a higher camera angle towards the print bed, suitable for smaller/flat objects.
The low version gives a loswer camera angle suitable for higher objects, and also reduces the printhead/fan covering is the item view.
The low version are also less sensitive to vibrations caused by rapid Y-zxis momements.

During rapid Y-axis momements of the 3D-printer bed, depending on weight, the camera may vibrate slightly. These vibrations are actually rarely noticable on the resulting time lapse movie, especially when using a camera with fish-eye lens.
Vibrations are reduced with higher infill.

Please note that this mount is designed for the Lulzbot Mini v1.04 (has BLACK bed plate).

title: Universal Filament Holder with ABEC bearings

description.text:
Having purchased a Flashforge Finder which uses 600g spools of filament, I needed a filament spool holder to support the larger 1kg spools of filament. I had already tried another design of holder but found the filament wrapped around the open wheel of this design and consequently tipped the whole spool holder over (6 hours into a 9 hour print!). There also seemed to be some resistance in the rotation of the wheels in this design so my design goals became 1) enclosed wheels and 2) minimum resistance to the rotation of the spool of filament.

I designed the parts of this spool holder using Solidworks. It is the first time I designed anything in 3d and to create your own holder you will need to print 2 brackets, 4 axle caps, 4 axles and 4 wheels. The wheels are designed to accept an ABEC9 608 steel (skateboard) bearing so you will need 4 of these too (eBay/Amazon etc.). The bearing is 22mm od, 8mm id and 7mm deep.

Note: There is a 'lip' inside each wheel to act as a bearing stop and the bearing is pressed into the wheel so the inner bearing face rests against this lip. The bearings are a tight fit so I lightly sanded the internal surface of the bearing housing and I used an additional bearing as a drift to gently tap each bearing into place.

When the bearing has been seated properly against the lip, the axle and axle cap are then added to complete the wheel. Two completed wheels are then snapped into each bracket. No glue is used in the construction but you may have to lightly sand the ends of the axels and axel caps to get an interference fit in the bracket. I noticed the Flashforge Finder prints produced a slight radial 'bulge' at the point where each axle and axle cap print was in contact with the print bed and these bulges had to be smoothed off before the parts would fit.

In use, I found the resistance to the turning of the filament spool is reduced to a minimum thereby maximising the efficiency of the filament feeding into the extruder. It is also now impossible for the filament to snag on the wheels. However, the function of the holder could be further improved by using more expensive ceramic bearings rather than the steel bearings used here. I am sure the pulley wheel and bearing design would be of benefit in other projects. Enjoy!

title: Anet A8 Specific Y-Axis Carriage Plate Upgrade
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an upgrade to the fastened together h-frame y-axis carriage that is supplied with Anet A8 printer kits. Universal Prusa i3 carriage plates lack y-axis motor clearance and require modifications to be used. This design is a direct replacement, that requires no modifications, and does not reduced z-axis travel. I happen to have access to a laser cutter and 0.160" aluminum plate, so I designed this plate to improve performance and include some similar features I like from the Lulzbot 5 carriage plate.
I have added the option for mounting three bearings in an isosceles triangle pattern. The four corner holes are sized for M3 taps to utilize either the original A8 fasteners, or to use the Lulzbot style 3D printed bed clamps.
I've also included center holes for M3 fasteners for those interested in using a 3 point leveling system. The belt retainer holes are sized for M4 taps and spaced for use with either the original Plexiglas bars, or the printed toothed retainers available here on Thingiverse.
Also added in a revision are the original h-frame M4 bolt pattern, on the motherboard side, that are used for the y-axis cable chain upgrade.
The overhung tabs with slots are for cable management or to mount any accessories desired.
All threaded holes will require tapping after cutting. Enjoy!

Autodesk Inventor Model

I have provided the original solid model from Autodesk Inventor as well as a drawing format Inventor file. Different nesting programs for laser cutters require different file formats, so I have provided both files I needed to manufacture this design.

comments.author: hamster153

comments.text: The triangles were just convenient shapes for ventilation and weight reduction. This design does support 3-point to 8-point leveling, I have found using 4 or 8 points is superior due to the bowed build plates typically provided with the A8. Essentially if your bed surface isn't perfectly flat, and most aren't even after adding glass, holding the tightest average height over the whole area is easiest with as many control points as possible. This is best accomplished with 8 fasteners, in this case, 4 in the corners and 4 in the center of each side. Larger commercial machines even have adjustment points in the middle of the bed, but that is difficult to apply to an A8. Most people don't use this method because of the modifications required and due to the thought that the bed needs constant adjustment. I have found once the level and flatness of the bed is properly adjusted it doesn't need to be adjusted again unless something else changes or you have a severe crash. The bed doesn't need to be truly level, which is why a level isn't used for adjustment. The side to side pitch of the bed should be parallel to the x-axis gantry after the gantry has been adjusted to run smoothly on the z-axis. The front to back bed pitch should be parallel to the y-axis rails. This will result in the most consistent first layer thickness. First layer nozzle height should then be adjusted with whatever style z-stop being used, whether physical or induction type.

comments.author: Tsunagioshi

comments.text: This component was designed to be plug and play, if desired. The bed leveling screw holes were designed so they could be tapped as in the OEM H-bracket design, but I recommend drilling them out to be clearance holes for use with leveling nuts. Lock nuts are not required as used in the OEM design. The spring tension alone is adequate to retain adjustment position. The OEM wing nuts will work, but I chose to upgrade to hex nuts with printed round knobs for two reasons. The knobs I used have a numbered scale that assists in fine adjustments, and the plastic knobs insulate your fingers from the heat transferred from the bed. I also epoxied the leveling screw heads to the countersinks in the bed itself to prevent slippage of the bolt as I adjust the nuts. All these suggestions are optional as the component can be used in exactly the same manner as the OEM component.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed this at 45% infill, .1mm res, and 30 mm/s because I only wanted to print it once. You could probably go lower, through the quality of the threads is going to effect the seal. You may not want to go lower on the infill (may not be bad to go higher) so the piece can hold the water pressure.

title: Garden Hose to Shower (1/2" IPT) adapter

description.text:
I needed an adapter from a garden hose to shower (1/2" IPT - Which is the standard us size) for my Jacuzzi tub. I could not find one. I used the adapter below to go from the garden tub faucet to garden hose (has a quick disconnect feature), b/c I could not find something to do what I needed. I used a standard garden hose gasket inside this (there are even some on thingiverse that you can print out if you really want to).

Danco 1052 Snap Coupling: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00GP9G860/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

This printed out well for me upside down on the shower fitting. Because I printed it with brim, I had a bit of a hard time getting it in the shower hose, so I heated that thread A LITTLE BIT and it went right in. Unless you are very confident with your printer's bridging capabilities, do no print it with the hose side down or the flat surface inside where the hose washer sits to seal it up will not be flat enough to seal well.

Edit

A year later and this thing is still working well even with almost daily use (don't judge me).

title: REPTIL Martian (Alien Clone) 30° GoPro Session mount

description.text:
This is a 30° GoPro Session mount for Martian II (Alien Clone) quadcopters. I additionally use the cam-ring from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2060314

To protect your camera, you can use the following thing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2516805

Please be aware, that there seem to be different sized Martian frames. This mount is designed for the ones with the following measurements:

  • The space between the front holes is 30.5mm
  • The space between the middle holes is 22.5mm
  • The distance between the front and middle holes is 56mm
  • All holes have a diameter of 3mm.
    All distances are measured from the center point of the hole.

title: Minimalistic bike brake lever
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
We assume no responsibility for this thing, at all! Use at your own risk, and be careful!

This experiment began with a bike without brakes. It had a clean look but it was very stupid to ride it in traffic.

We wanted to see if we could create a simple and discrete front brake lever, since most of the ones we've seen are very ugly. This is a simplification, as it is the smallest amount of volume and visual impact we could get to work (however, we leave no guarantee on this). Safety and self-preservation not included.

This design will only work with centre-pull caliper brakes or similar. Print one clip and one lever. Attach with M4 bolt and locknut.

2017-01-25
Proof of concept. First test period done. Hardware needed: 35mm long M4 bolt and a locknut. Designing a lower profile clip.

2017-10-09
The test lever broke today! It has been kept outside for a few weeks, and this morning was especially cold. A new lever will be printed, maybe in PET or ABS. Or maybe just with 100% infill.

If anyone would decide to try this, we would really appreciate any input you might have.

We printed this with 23% infill using black PLA. We have tested it for almost a year, and it is working very well. We have been careful not to expose it to the elements for longer times than necessary.

Despite this, we REALLY advise you to print it with 100% infill, and to keep it away from heat, sun, chemicals, rain, cats and heavy machinery. If you still want to use it, that is.

author: TheLegend27

description.text: This is a 14 in 1 sewing measurement tool. I designed this for a friend that needed one for sewing. I think it is used for measuring the width of a hem. Some of the measurements are labeled with raised letters. There are other hidden measurements that are not labeled. The with across one axis is 2 inches and 2 1/4. The measurements across the other axis is 1 1/2 inches. Someone edited this design and made a cool version compatible with laser cutters. Find that here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1603026

I would recommend printing this with 0.3mm layers as the numbers on the top are 0.3mm high. I sanded the numbers to smooth them out as to not catch on the fabric when in use. After sanding I used a paint pen to highlight the numbers. I have included the Sketchup file if you would like to edit the original. I also included an STL file with no measurements.

Reference design for the Pololu Adjustable Boost Regulator 4-25V
http://tienda.bricogeek.com/fuentes-de-alimentacion/184-conversor-dc-ajustable-4-25v.html

Manufacturer website:
https://www.pololu.com/product/799

This is an edit of my double ball bearing fidget spinner here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1821445

Update 2:
I have just uploaded a curved rendition of the original spinner which uses only the 1/2" ball bearings, but I can upload the 5/8" if people want them. I find this one much nicer looking and much nicer to spin. This model has a slightly oversized skate bearing hole because I found myself having to sand out the inside of the hole for half an hour each time I printed a spinner, if this causes problems for you guys with more precise printers let me know and I'll upload one with tighter tolerances.

Update:
I have just uploaded a second model which uses 1/2" (12.7mm) ball bearings instead of the 5/8" (15.875mm) ones if you prefer lighter weight or can't find the 5/8" ones.

It uses three 5/8" ball bearings as the weights, which is 15.875mm for everyone else in the world. These were originally superglued in, I left the ends open because I think it looks and feels better that way, but I redesigned it to be a little thicker and the balls now just snap in and hold just fine.

If you made one, post a photo! Thanks!

Printer:

Geeetech G2S Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

You may have issues with warping, if so just put a ~3mm brim around it and it should be fine. Printed in PLA at 200 degrees.
Rotate the model 90 degrees on the X axis to print flat, sorry about that.

Materials/Instructions

You will need:
1 "Skate" 608 bearing
3 5/8" (15.875mm) Ball bearings (10 pack for like $4 on Amazon)
or
3 1/2" (12.7mm) Ball bearings

The skate bearing and ball bearings just press in, you may need to sand or file down the inside for the skate bearing to fit depending on your printer.

author: harlev

description.text:
Watch here: https://youtu.be/kszk8a_kub8

Who doesn't love a good Claptrap? Well lots of people I guess, but I really like this little guy. His antics kept me entertained through the Borderlands games so I knew that I wanted to create one of these for myself.

I created the model in Fusion 360. I used sketches almost exclusively to create this. I started out by lofting two sketches together to get the main body shape. Then I just proceeded to sketch out all the details I could see. I resized as I went to make sure everything looked proportional.

After it I printed it out (settings below), I handed it off to my wife who sanded the crap out of it, glued it together, primed it, and painted it using a combination of spray paint, airbrush, and paintbrush techniques.

Print Settings:
Printer: Robo 3D R1
Filament: Hatchbox PLA
Layer Height: 0.1mm
Infill: 20%
Supports/Raft: Yes

title: Tevo Black Widow - Titan Extruder Mount

description.text:
Simple mount for an E3D Titan Extruder to the Tevo Black Widow 3D printer.

Use M5 screws and M5 lock nuts to mount to Black Widow X carriage.

There are two mounting positions. The higher position (using lower nut recesses) will work for E3D Volcano or other long hot ends. The lower position (using upper nut recesses) will work for E3D V6 or similar length hot ends.

Note: the pictures are from a previous version of the design. After mounting it I realized that the mount would be too high if I had a standard V6 hot end instead of a Volcano.

remixed_from.author: Starwhooper
remixed_from.title: Holder for  Auto Leveling Position Sensor for Anet A8 Prusa i3

title: Anet A8 SN04-N Auto Leveling Sensor Bracket

description.text:
This is a rework of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2019216 . This version adds additional cable management, a holder for the not-easily-accessible sensor nuts, and a design that uses the 8mm linear slider bearings to align the bracket. If you’re using a full cooling fan ring you’ll need to move to a half ring: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1954001

Sliced using Cura with the standard Anet A8 settings. The bracket used the normal profile, and the nut holder used high quality.

Standard Anet A8 Cura settings can be found in the comments section of the setup video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gSXFHd-UDmE

The Marlin Configuration.h settings:
I determined these offsets using the grid file "Coords mm.pdf"
define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -11 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 31 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
The Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER setting should be set based on your actual results during setup. See https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tTl09r-E0wE . Note that the video uses Cura. I wasn’t able to get Cura to see the Anet board on my Mac so I used the Repetier-Host Mac.app.
define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -0.6 // Z offset: -below +above [the nozzle]

Update: See the comment from T3rorX. T3rorX has found the bed position settings I provide below to not be optimal. I'm no longer using this sensor so I'll let you decide which to use.

I was kind of iffy on these 4 settings:
define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 15
define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 195
define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 205
define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 25

Hardware: (2) M3 x 25, (2) M3 x 20. (It will work with longer versions of either, these are the exact sizes.)

Make sure you use thread locker such as https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000I1RSNS. I found that the sensor screws will loosen causing the sensor to drift closer to the bed if it's not secured tightly. When this happens it shows up as poor first layer adhesion.

I got the SN04-N sensor on eBay. There’s a huge range in price depending on whether you buy it with or without the connector. I got two for US $7.42 (from a US vendor) and added the connector myself. It came out cheaper than some of the assembled sensors, and you end up with a useful crimping tool for XH2.54 and JST 2.0 PH connectors.

Sensor: http://www.ebay.com/itm/351861131683
Connector: http://www.ebay.com/itm/252489099827
Crimping tool: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00YGLKBSK

title: Heavy Duty Spool Insert Filament Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Fits 57mm filament spools perfectly. Add a small board, a 1/4-20 bolt, a few nuts and a washer or two and you've got a nice top mount spool holder. This would be very well suited to an enclosed printer where the lid of the enclosure can be used to attach the bolt.

UPDATE: I came across some spools that didn't fit the 57mm version. I've uploaded a 52mm STL to cover a wider range of filament.

There is a .5mm recess on the bottom to suit a washer, and potentially some type of lubricant if you should desire. The spool boss and center gudgeon are reinforced with ribs and fillets. This is likely complete overkill, but it sure does look cool.

I have included a copy in STEP format, in case you want to edit it as a solid model.

title: Bowden Heatbreak 40mm Fan Clip Duct
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I printed this for my "RepRap Champion J-head V6 Hotend" that I got on Amazon. The fan that I had was small and the clip did not fit the heatbreak. It is designed for a 22mm diameter, 26mm height heatbreak, and accommodates a 40mm fan (fastener holes are spaced 32mm on center).

Please note that the holes are 3.8mm in diameter. This was intended for 4mm bolts, but I undersized the holes so that I could cleanly drill them once done printing.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Steel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4 nozzle, 0.2 layer height

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I used PLA, and the clip seems to be holding up after a putting on and taking off a couple of times, but I will upgrade to ABS if it breaks.
I scraped the inside of the duct with a pocket knife and then sanded in order to remove the plastic strings from my printer head moving over the gap.

This was designed using Fusion 360 using the following process:

  1. In the XY plane, create the block that attaches to the fan by extruding a square, subtracting the bolt holes (extruded circles), and filleting the corners.

  2. Create a 38mm circle on the fan side and a 34mm circle on the clip side of the block.

  3. Use the loft tool to loft one of these circles to the other. This subtracts the duct through the block portion.

  4. In the XZ or YZ plane, create a profile of the clip. This consists of a 22mm inner diameter and a 26mm outer diameter.

  5. Use an 18mm wide rectangle to approximate the location of the clip's hole. Symmetrically place 2mm diameter circles at the clip openings.

  6. Place a rectangle on the block side of the clip profile. This should be 26mm wide and extend to its tangent with the larger created in step 4, but be at least 10mm from the nearest side of the block.

  7. Use the trim tool to remove all excess portions of the profile for the clip. Be sure to leave the entire inner diameter of the clip clear so that it will fit over the heatbreak.

  8. Extrude the profile to 26mm.

  9. In the XY plane, create a rectangle at the height coincident to the widest point of the clip's inner diameter. Ensure that it is 22mm by 22mm and is centered over the clip. This allows 2mm thickness on each side.

  10. Extrude the rectangle created in step 9 through the clip, creating a clear duct towards the block.

  11. First, loft the outer rectangle of the clip to the outer circle of the rim on the block. Next, loft the inner rectangle of the clip to the inner circle of the block's rim. This will be subtracted from the shape, creating the middle section of duct.

Your design is complete!

An alternate front cover for the E3D Titan extruder. This cover allows swapping the hot end without releasing the inner mechanism (spring, gear, etc.).

I did not want to remove the bearing from the original cover, so I made a version that uses a MR105-2RS bearing instead. (MR105-2RS bearings are used in mini v-slot wheels.) If anyone prints the version for the original bearing please let me know how the fit is so I can adjust the model if needed.

I also created two different thicknesses of the hot swap cover and two different spacers for the upper screws. These different thicknesses can help accommodate different thicknesses of Titan mounts without having to cut the screws or get ones of a different length.

comments.text: I just made a new carriage for my printer and this will really help with clearing jams.  I have already lost the spring from taking apart the original cover getting the hot end out.  That won't happen with this design.  This is the next project to print up.

author: Choo2017

title: Bracelet with scale shaped holes
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Just a quick stab at repeated patterns. This came out looking good on the computer screen, but when I printed it, I wasn't too thrilled. Maybe it was because of the translucent red filament I was using. If anyone makes it in anything else, maybe it might look better?  
Maybe metal, or metalic plastic. Or maybe printed at a better resolution.

I sort of cheated. I used this online service called ShapeShifter. I downloaded the STL, but the modeling software I use (Sketchup) kept freezing everytime I tried to flatten out the base of the bracelet.  
So if you want to print this thing, I can tell you what I did. I did on the fly calibration on the printer. When it printed the first layer, it was fine. But when it was printing the second layer, everytime it printed the edges that it had left out in the first layer, I lightly pushed the base closer to the extruder so the PLA would stick to the base rather than float in the air. I did this for layer 2-4 and then after the base looked round enough, I left it alone and it printed just fine for the rest of the print.  
If you want to print it, I suggest either flattening out the base, or doing what I did. OR, you can try to get this printed using UV Resin or Metal sintering. I'd love to see those results :-D  
Also, I printed at .2 mm, but I think the product would look better if printed on .1 mm

description.text:
UPDATE: Now each mount has it's own file...

Fan Mount for a 120mm fan for the Anet A2 motherboard, to keep if fresh.

-The same screws for the original plate can be used for this mount.
-8 screw to mount the fan (If you only have 4 of them, you can use 2 on each side of the fan)

Installation:
-Remove the front plate
-Place the four long screws in each hole in the small mount with the flat side facing the motherboard (See picture for reference)
-Place the 12cm fan in the side of the mount that has the fan support and screw it from the flat side of the mount. (See picture for reference)
-Install the plastic tubes in the long screws and attach the mount to the printer frame as it was at the beginning.
-Attach the big mount to the fan and put the screws on it.

Note: The more organized your cables are, the better the air will flow to the motherboard.



ACTUALIZACION: ahora las rejillas estan en archivos separados...

Rejilla de Montaje para ventilador de 12cm, para la tarjeta madre de la impresora Anet A2.

-Los mismos tornillos usados para montar la placa de acrilico original, son usados para montar la rejilla.
-8 tornillos para el ventilador (o en caso de que solo tengas cuatro, puedes usar dos en cada lado del ventilador)

Instalacion:
-Remover la placa frontal
-Colocar los 4 tornillos largos en la rejilla pequeña con el lado plano viendo hacia la tarjeta madre. (Ver imagen de referencia)
-Colocar el ventilador de 12cm sobre los pequeños soportes de la rejilla y atornillar el mismo desde el lado plano de la rejilla. (Ver imagen de referencia)
-Colocar los tubos de plastico en los tornillos largos y atornillar la rejilla en la placa que esta en la estructura de la impresora a como estaba al principio.
-Colocar la rejilla grande sobre el ventilador y atornillar.

Nota: Entre menos amontonados esten los cables, mejor sera el flujo de aire del ventilador a la tarjeta madre.

title: Belted lead screw drive for z axis
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
https://www.reddit.com/r/voroncorexy/comments/5q0hrl/v039_new_experimental_zdrive/

BUILD NOTES AND BOM:

My printer is a 12" build area voron corexy. I used 450mm 2020 extrusions for the frame so if you are adding this z drive remember to choose the length of your belts to fit your own frame area. Additionally you will need to figure out the length of lead screw that is appropriate for your own application (400mm lead screws worked for me).

You will need:

  • 4x KFL08 8mm Flange Pillow Block Bearings

  • 2x GT2 Driver Belt in Closed Loop Rubber L=976mm W=6mm 488 Teeth (size the belt to fit your own printers size, it has to be closed loop)

  • 2x GT2 Double Head Timing Belt Pulley - 20 Teeth - 8mm Bore

  • 1x GT2 Double Head Timing Belt Pulley - 20 Teeth - 5mm Bore

  • Feet to increase height under the extrusions so the pulley and motor housings can hang down; mine are located here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2068704

I'm thinking if I upgrade this system at all I'll move to a single gt3 belt but of course that means finding a supplier and pulleys as well.  Still nothing I can complain about with this system, still working great for me since I put it into service.
comments.author: mdroman

comments.text:
Thanks for sharing, this looks very clean. I plan on implementing this in my Voron build. Just a few questions:
1) Is there any particular reason for having both belts driving both leadscrews instead of one belt per leadscrew?
2) How is the correct tension in the belts achieved? do you slide both leadscrew mounts towards and away from the drive motor?
3) Is there anything you would do differently after experience with this design?
comments.author: zpbruno

comments.text: Hey no problem, I'm glad I could share it with everyone.
comments.author: zpbruno

comments.text: Thanks- makes complete sense!
comments.author: thetekguy

comments.text: Dumb question: Why two belts and double pulleys? Why not just one belt and single pulley to drive both leadscrews?
comments.author: thetekguy

comments.text: You could use just one belt, although if you want to go that route you might want to move be up to gt3 size belts. One gt2 6mm wide belt won't handle the weight of the entire z stage well at all. I went with two gt2 belts because the pulleys and belts were easily obtainable from amazon and uses materials we are all familiar with. If you could locate a supplier of gt3 belts and pulleys then I'd say try it out for sure.
comments.author: thetekguy

comments.text: Hi,
comments.author: KronBjorn

comments.text: I have thought about trying that myself, that would solve the problem of the slightly "tippy" carriage that I have going on now. The linear rods are great for ensuring directional travel but they aren't so great acting as support; so with my current bed carriage setup you have one real support per side (lead screw) and 2 linear rods ensuring it moves the carriage in a straight line on the z axis. Pressing on any point of the bed carriage, especially further out from the centered lead screw causes a tipping in the carriage off that centered screw point because the linear rods allow movement no matter what. It's not a deal breaker by any means and does function properly but I'm all for a more solid way of doing things if it functions well.
comments.author: KronBjorn

author: ILUVDONUTZ

description.text:
I have been working on this extruder cooler for my X3 and X3A printers for awhile now and it is now printing very well and working great!

I'm using a 30x30x10mm fan for the cool section and two 25x25x10mm fans for filament cooling. The design is very compact yet keeps the cool parts cool and lets the heat block get up to temperature fast.

Mounts in the same place as the stock fan and even uses the same screws.

The fans are all wired to the same wiring that powered the stock 40mm fan. Just make sure all red wires are together and all black wires too. The fans mount using 3mm sheet metal screws (#2 can be used too). As an option, you can wire the 25mm fans to the second fan connector on the Melzi controller board. They will not run during pre-heating but will come on during the print after the first couple of layers depending on how you have your slicer configured.

Designed to be printed in the upright position.

This cooler also has a easy to adjust inductive sensor mount. Use a 3mm x 25mm screw, 3mm nut and hot bed spring. Works great and makes adjusting the Z gap super easy. This also works with the X3S printer.

Because the cooler is wide and is used to trigger the X limit switch, I put a G10 X-100 command in the start code of CURA just before the printing starts. This gets the bed center back to where it needs to be for centering your prints on the heat bed. YMMV depending on if you have a X3 or X3A or X3S.

Printer:

Tronxy X3A

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

25

Sensor Mount

The sensor mount can be modified if you want to use a capacitive sensor. I'm using the stock inductive sensor and printing on PEI.

I used a 3mm screw and a spring so that the sensor can be easily adjusted.
This was the most complex design I have done so far using Design Spark Mechanical but overall it was pretty easy. I really like DSM and it's FREE!

comments.text: Hi
comments.author: Panzergruppe

comments.text: All of the fans are connected to the same wiring as the original 40mm single fan.
comments.author: Panzergruppe

comments.text: These fans are very small and therefore you need more of them to get the proper airflow. The top fan is used to cool the upper portion of the hot end and the two lower fans are used to cool the print. Cooling the print helps with bridging and also small objects. I chose these fans in order to make the cooler fit in as small of an area as I could while still doing a proper job.

description.text:
RECEPTION FURNITURE DESIGN BY FECTECH
FOLLOW @fectech1 - instagram

inspired in bumerang - for for Stevie Wonder Exposition

The bone conducting speaker on Google Glass is more effective when pressed firmly against the side of your skull. Several folks on the Google+ Glass Explorer community have tried using various hacks to extend the speaker's contact surface. This is a simple, parametric item modeled in FreeCAD which I've used to do the same. You can adjust the pad property of the part to make the extension deeper or shallower as necessary.

I sliced at 0.15mm because the item is fairly small and there is a tiny fillet on the top edge for comfort.  
Otherwise, pretty straightforward print.

This is a super simple part for my Maker Ultimate, but it serves a valuable purpose. Without some kind of guide, the filament occasionally slips around the outside of the spool and stops un-spooling as the print progresses (especially on a brand new/full role).

While there are more sophisticated solutions that add Bowden tubes and lots of guide clips and what not, this one is good enough to get me printing fun stuff again fast.

On the back of the cabinet frame, just behind the Y-axis motor, is a little slot about 6mm x 18mm. Simply push the mount through this slot from the inside and then slide the guide into the notch on the outside. (see photo)

title: Medusa - 180mm Peristaltic Pump
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a pump for a barbot I'm making. The swingarm needs some edits, so here's the basic.

2/16/17 - Made the edits and combined the motor plate and the main body of the pump. I'll post results when the 12 hour print complets!

As of 2/9/17 I need to make the pump body 6mm wider to fit the overlap of the hose entrance/exit

It gets its name as the hoses will rise out of the top, you get enough of these together, and well its Medusa! I have a 100mm version of this and also plan to make a 140mm version.

Quick dimensions, it has a 200mm outer diameter and a 180mm inner diameter. It's made for 7/16" silicone hose. It will fit a nema 17 motor, and shaft.

Pressure Wheels will use an 8mm inner diameter skateboard wheel bearing because well, they're cheap enough. I'll get the updated files up around Monday!

This work is based on the peristaltic pump by Leland

author: jmatonis

title: Spacer for SSR mount for Trick Laser MAX Metal

description.text:
This will help you mount an Auber Instruments 100-amp SSR + heat sink to your MAX Metal frame. Print these with as many loops as it takes to make them 100% solid, and use the toughest filament you have.

WARNING: These come with NO WARRANTY OF ANY KIND. Use them at your own risk. I have not tested these on a live machine. You might want to use metal washers instead. If you do want to print and use these, the best filament (to my knowledge) would be Taulman BluPrint. It's rated to withstand boiling temperatures for several hours. The heat they're subject to will depend on air temperature, whether you're using an enclosure, and heat being radiated down by the Onyx as well as the motors and other electronics. I've used these SSRs at 12 volts, and the heat sinks never get perceptibly above room temperature. If you run yours at a higher voltage - most people use 24V - the heat sink will get warmer, but I can't say by how much.

That said, I don't anticipate any problems with any of the above. I'm warning you all the same, so you can make an intelligent decision.

These spacers are for use with the following:
Auber 100-Amp SSR
Auber HS25 Heat Sink

You will also need Unbrako #10-32 x 1/2" screws and 80/20 Inc. Roll-In T-Slot Nuts.

After fastening the heat sink to the SSR (don't forget the thermal paste), install one of these spacers on each of two Unbrako screws, then screw the SSR to the T-slot nuts. Refer to the photos above.

IMPORTANT: Do not over-tighten. Inspect the spacers for cracks after installation, whenever the printer is moved or jostled, and every now and then (at your discretion). You DO NOT want your SSR to fall down inside the printer!
